adverb &amp; preposition.description: At or to the further side of.
examples: he pointed to a spot beyond the trees
passengers traveling to destinations beyond Boston
there was the terminal and, beyond, an endless line of warehouses

adverb &amp; preposition.description: Happening or continuing after (a specified time or event)
examples: music going on into the night and beyond
we can manage another two years, but beyond that the system is not viable

adverb &amp; preposition.description: Having progressed or achieved more than (a specified stage or level)
examples: we need to get beyond square one

adverb &amp; preposition.description: To or in a degree or condition where a specified action is impossible.
examples: the landscape has changed beyond recognition
beyond telling us that she was well educated, he has nothing to say about her
there was little vegetation beyond scrub and brush

origin: Old English begeondan, from be by + geondan of Germanic origin (related to yon and yonder).
